introduction.p: With the Pythagorean theorem we can find one side of a right triangle if we know the other two sides. By using what we know about similar triangles, we can find the unknown sides of a right triangle if we know only one side and one of the acute angles.

subsection.title: The Sine of an Angle

sidebyside.p: In Example 2 of Section 1.2, we saw that in a 30-60-90 right triangle, the ratio of the shortest side to the hypotenuse was \frac{1}{2}, or 0.5. This ratio is the same for any two right triangles with a 30\degree angle, because they are similar triangles, as shown at right.

subsection.p: The ratio is given a name; it is called the "sine of 30\degree." We write \sin (30\degree) = 0.5, where sin is an abbreviation for sine. There is nothing special about 30\degree angles; we can talk about the sine of any angle. The sine of an angle is the ratio of the side opposite the angle to the hypotenuse.

note.p: Recall that we use the notation f(x) to indicate a function of an input variable, x. In fact, the sine ratio is a function of the angle, so we use parentheses around the angle input to refer to its sine, like this: \sin (\theta).

statement.p: Find the sine of the labeled angle in each triangle below.

li.p: The side opposite angle \phi is 5, and the hypotenuse is 13, so the sine of \phi is \sin (\phi) =\dfrac{5}{13}, \text{ or approximately}~~ 0.3846
The side opposite angle \beta is \sqrt{5}, and the hypotenuse is 3, so the sine of \beta is \sin (\beta) =\dfrac{\sqrt{5}}{3}, \text{ or approximately}~~ 0.7454

stack.p: We must use the sides of a right triangle to calculate the sine of an angle. For example, in the triangle at right, \sin (\theta)=\frac{4}{7}, because \triangle ABC is a right triangle.
It is not true that \sin (\theta)=\frac{5}{7}, or \sin (\theta)=\frac{6}{7}. In this chapter, we consider only right triangles.

subsection.title: Using a Calculator
subsection.p: Mathematicians have calculated the sines of any angle we like. The values of the sine were originally collected into tables, and are now available on scientific calculators. For example, let's find the sine of 50\degree. First, consider some triangles, as shown below.
Do you expect the sine of 50\degree to be larger or smaller than the sine of 30\degree? Do you expect the sine of 50\degree to be larger or smaller than 1?

statement.p: Use your calculator to find the sine of 50\degree by entering SIN (50). (Make sure your calculator is set for degrees.) You should find that \sin (50\degree) = 0.7660444431 This is not an exact value; the sine of 50\degree is an irrational number, and your calculator shows as many digits as its display will allow. (Not all sine values are as “nice” as the sine of 30\degree!) Usually we round to four decimal places, so we write \sin (50\degree) = 0.7660

warning.p: Note that when you press the sine key, SIN, your calculator displays \large{\text{sin}}~ ( with an open parenthesis, as the prompt to enter an angle, because the sine is a function of the angle.
You can think of the notation sin as an operation symbol telling you to find the sine of an angle, just as the symbol \sqrt{~~} tells you to take the square root of the expression under the radical.

li.p: Use your calculator to complete the table, rounding your answers to four decimal places.

ol.li: What do you notice about the values of \sin (\theta) as \theta increases from 0 \degree to 90 \degree? If you plot the values of \sin (\theta) against the values of \theta, will the graph be a straight line? Why or why not?

li.p: The values of \sin (\theta) increase from 0 to 1 as \theta increases from 0\degree to 90\degree. The graph will not be a straight line because the slopes between successive points are not constant.

note.p: The important thing to remember is that the sine of an angle, say 50 \degree, is the same for any right triangle with a 50 \degree angle, no matter what the size or orientation of the triangle.

The figure below shows three different right triangles with a 50 \degree angle. Although the sides of the triangle may be bigger or smaller, the ratio \dfrac {\text{opposite}}{\text{hypotenuse}} is always the same for that angle, because the triangles are similar. This is why the sine ratio sine ratiosine ratiosine is useful.

subsection.title: Using the Sine Ratio to Find an Unknown Side

idx.h: using to find an unknown side

subsection.p: In the next example we see how to use the sine ratio to find an unknown side in a right triangle, knowing only one other side and one angle.

sidebyside.p: Find the length of the side opposite the 50 \degree angle in the triangle shown.

solution.p: In this triangle, the ratio \dfrac {\text{opposite}}{\text{hypotenuse}} is equal to the sine of 50 \degree, or \sin (50\degree) = \dfrac {\text{opposite}}{\text{hypotenuse}} We use a calculator to find an approximate value for the sine of 50 \degree, filling in the lengths of the hypotenuse and the opposite side to get 0.7660 = \dfrac {x}{18} We solve for x to find x = 18(0.7660)=13.788 To two decimal places, the length of the opposite side is 13.79 centimeters.

warning.p: In the previous example, even though we showed only four places in \sin (50\degree), you should not round off intermediate steps in a calculation, because the answer loses accuracy with each rounding. You can use the following keystrokes on your calculator to avoid entering a long approximation for \sin (50\degree): \text{sin}~(50)~\times 18 The calculator returns x=13.78879998.

subsection.title: The Cosine and the Tangent
subsection.p: There are two more trigonometric ratios used for calculating the sides of right triangles, depending on which of the three sides is known and which are unknown. These ratios are called the cosine and the tangent.

Suppose we'd like to find the height of a tall cliff without actually climbing it. We can measure the distance to the base of the cliff, and we can use a surveying tool called a theodolite to measure the angle between the ground and our line of sight to the top of the cliff (this is called the angle of elevation).

sidebyside.p: These values give us two parts of a right triangle, as shown at right. The height we want is the side opposite the angle of elevation. The distance to the base of the cliff is the length of the side adjacent to the angle of elevation.

subsection.p: The ratio of the side opposite an angle to the side adjacent to the angle is called the tangenttangent of the angle. The abbreviation for “tangent of theta” is tan (\theta)tan \theta.

Just like the sine of an angle, the tangent ratio is always the same for a given angle, no matter what size triangle it occurs in. And just like \sin (\theta), we can find the values of \tan (\theta) on a scientific calculator.

ol.li: Use your calculator to find the tangent of 58 \degree.
Find the height of the cliff if the angle of elevation to the top of the cliff is 58 \degree at a distance of 300 feet from the base of the cliff.
Enter TAN (58) to find \tan (58\degree) = 1.6003, rounded to four decimal places.

sidebyside.p: We use the tangent ratio to write an equation. In this triangle, the angle is 58 \degree. \tan (58\degree) = \dfrac{\text{opposite}}{\text{adjacent}}

li.p: Next we fill in the value of \tan (58\degree), and the lengths of the sides. 1.6003 = \frac{h}{300} Solving for h gives h = 300(1,6003) = 480.0 so the height of the cliff is about 480 feet.

subsection.p: The third trigonometric ratio, called the cosine, is the ratio of the side adjacent to an angle and the hypotenuse of the triangle.

sidebyside.p: Find \sin (\theta),~ \cos (\theta), and \tan (\theta) for the triangle shown at right.

solution.p: First, we use the Pythagorean theorem to find the hypotenuse, c. c^2 \amp =6^2 + 8^2 c^2 \amp = 536=84 = 100 \amp\amp \blert{\text{Take square roots.}} c \amp = \sqrt{100} = 10 For the angle \theta, the opposite side is 8 inches long, and the adjacent side is 6 inches long, as shown in the figure. Thus, \sin (\theta) \amp = \dfrac{\text{opposite}}{\text{hypotenuse}} = \frac{8}{10}~~ \text{or}~~ 0.8 \cos (\theta) \amp = \dfrac{\text{adjacent}}{\text{hypotenuse}} = \frac{6}{10} ~~ \text{or}~~ 0.6 \tan (\theta) \amp = \dfrac{\text{opposite}}{\text{adjacent}} = \frac{8}{6} ~~ \text{or}~~1.\overline{3}

ol.li: What do you notice about the values of sine and cosine? Can you explain why this is true? (Hint: If one (non-right) angle of a right triangle measures x degrees, how big is the other angle? Now sketch the triangle and label the opposite and adjacent sides for each angle.)

li.p: The cosine of \theta is equal to the sine of the complement of \theta, or \cos (\theta) = \sin (90-\theta).

note.p: In the previous exercise, you should also notice that as the angle \theta increases, \sin (\theta) increases but \cos (\theta) decreases.

You can see why this is true in the figure below. In each right triangle, the hypotenuse has the same length. But as the angle increases, the opposite side gets longer and the adjacent side gets shorter.

We must also be careful to apply these definitions of the trigonometric ratios only to right triangles. In the next example, we create a right triangle by drawing an extra line.

statement.p: The vertex angle of an isosceles triangle is 34 \degree, and the equal sides are 16 meters long. Find the altitude of the triangle.

sidebyside.p: The triangle described is not a right triangle. However, the altitude of an isosceles triangle bisects the vertex angle and divides the triangle into two congruent right triangles, as shown in the figure. The 16-meter side becomes the hypotenuse of the right triangle, and the altitude, h, of original triangle is the side adjacent to the 17\degree angle.

solution.p: Which of the three trig ratios is helpful in this problem? The cosine is the ratio that relates the hypotenuse and the adjacent side, so we'll begin with the equation \cos (17\degree) =\dfrac{\text{adjacent}}{\text{hypotenuse}} We use a calculator to find \cos (17\degree) and fill in the lengths of the sides. 0.9563 = \dfrac {h}{16} Solving for h gives h = 16(0.9563) = 15.3008 The altitude of the triangle is about 15.3 meters long.
